characters: INT. SCOUT MASTER WARD'S TENT. NIGHT
INT. SCOUT MASTER WARD'S TENT. DAY
CAPTAIN SHARP/MR. BISHOP SCOUT MASTER WARD/MRS. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A landing at the top of a crooked, wooden staircase. Ther a threadbare, braided rug on the floor. There is a long, corridor decorated with faded paintings of sailboats and battleships. The wallpapers are sun-bleached and peeling the corners except for a few newly-hung strips which are clean and bright. A small easel sits stored in the corner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, a hard rain falls, drumming the roof and rattlin the gutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ten-year-old boy in pajamas comes up the steps carefull eating a bowl of cereal as he walks. He is Lionel. Lionel slides open the door to a low cabinet under the window. H takes out a portable record player, puts a disc on the turntable, and sets the needle into the spinning groove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A child's voice says over the speaker:

dialogues.speaker: RECORD PLAYER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In order to show you how a big symphony orchestra is put together, Benjamin Britten has written a big piece of music, which is made up of smaller pieces that show you all the separate parts of the orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lionel listens, three other children wander out of the bedrooms and down to the landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first is an eight-year-old boy in a bathrobe. He is Murray. The second is a nine-year-old boy in white boxer shorts and a white undershirt. He is Rudy. The third is a twelve-year-old girl in a cardigan sweater with knee-high socks and brightly polished, patent-leather shoes. She is Suzy. She carries a one-month-old striped kitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys drop down to the floor next to their brother. Th lie on their stomachs with their chins propped up on thei fists, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy sits in the windowsill. She opens a book called Shel and the Secret Universe. There is an illustration on the cover of a young gymnast with a glowing amulet around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy starts to read -- then pauses. She lowers her book. raises a pair of junior binoculars to her eyes. She looks into the rain. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rickety, three-story, stone-and-shingle house on a hill with turrets and a widow's walk. A weather vane swings creaking on the roof. Tree tops sway in a cluster below. sea is almost invisible in the misting rain, and the main is a shadow across the sound. Suzy sits in the high windo watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family stuck indoors all day out of the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In bedrooms, bathrooms, and corridors, we see the boys. T shoot marbles. They throw jacks. They play cards. They ea grilled cheese sandwiches together in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In half-open doorways, we see the parents. Mr. Bishop is tall, fifty-year-old man in Madras trousers and horn-rimm glasses. He reads the newspaper and drinks coffee. Mrs. Bishop is a tan, forty-five-year-old woman in a Lilly Pulitzer-type wrap-around skirt. She washes her hair, topless, in the kitchen sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In windows, we see Suzy with her binoculars. She watches branches shaking in the woods. She watches a man in a sli fishing from a row-boat. She watches a white colt in a fi She eats a bowl of tomato soup alone in the pantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, a seaplane flies by below the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The edge of a cliff above a white beach. A rocky peninsul curls into the background. Brisk wind rustles the tall gr A fifty-year-old man, bald on top with long hair on the sides, stands next to a surveyor's levelling instrument o tripod. He wears rubber boots and a parka. He is the narrator. He speaks to the camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the island of New Penzance. Sixteen miles long. Forested with old- growth pine and maple. Criss-crossed by shallow tidal creeks. An important seabird habitat. There are no paved roads but instead many miles of intersecting foot paths and dirt trails and a ferry that runs twice daily from Stone Cove. The year is 1965. We are on the far edge of Black Beacon Sound, famous for the ferocious and well-documented storm which will strike from the east on the fifth of September -- in three day's time. 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clearing in the woods with ten small, khaki tents pitch in a row. A banner on a flag-pole ripples in the wind. It reads Camp Ivanhoe. A bugler in a khaki uniform with a ye neckerchief plays a staccato tattoo. He has a gauze patch over one eye. He is Lazy-Eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thirty-five-year-old man in the same uniform emerges through the flaps of a larger tent. He is Scout Master Wa He puts on a wide-brimmed felt hat. A badge on the crown reads Khaki Scouts, Troop 55. He lights a cigarette. A th scout with curly hair and sunglasses joins him at his sid He is Gadge.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Morning, Gadge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gadge flips open a small, spiral-bound note-book. Scout Master Ward goes over to a latrine made from thick sticks rope. A tall, stooped scout digs a trench next to it with army-shovel. He is Deluca.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Deluca. Latrine inspection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deluca stops digging. He pulls on a rope and water runs d a chute. It bursts through a valve, spins a little door, a small, red flag flips up. Scout Master Ward nods.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gadge makes a note. Scout Master Ward strides away. He st in front of a scout with long hair over his eyes sitting stump twisting something in his fingers. He is Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Roosevelt. How's that lanyard coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I think I skipped a stitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, woven, multi-colored cord with a rabbit's foot attached to the end of it. It has been braided exceedingl badly and is brutally twisted and misshapen. 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward studies the lanyard briefly. He looks perplexed. He pats Roosevelt on the back gently and does secret handshake with him. Gadge makes a note. Scout Mast Ward strides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An off-road motorcycle races by in the background behind tents. It jumps a mound of dirt, kicks sideways in the ai and revs away riding a wheelie. Scout Master Ward frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward stops in front of a pile of boards and stacked six feet high. A thick-set scout with black hair a crooked tooth approaches with more logs in his arms. He Skotak.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Skotak. What's all this lumber for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're building a tree house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skotak points up. Scout Master Ward squints. There is a s platform under construction about sixty feet above them. scouts are sawing something in half on it. Scout Master W looks astonished.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: That's not a safe altitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward circles around the trunk while looking at the tree house. He stammers:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Why's it up so high? If somebody falls -- it's a guaranteed death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, where would you've built it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lower!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gadge makes a note. Skotak looks sheepish. Scout Master W strides away. He stops in front of a very small scout wit tiny eyes poking at an anthill with a stick. He appears t contemplating pouring lighter fluid on it. He is Nickleby

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Nickleby. Spot check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nickleby stands up. He looks extremely disheveled. 5.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Your socks are down. Your shirt-tails are untucked. Your trousers are not properly pressed. You are reported for uniform violation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gadge makes a note. Nickleby slouches. Scout Master Ward strides away. He stops in front of a work-bench covered w newspaper where one scout sifts green powder through a fu into cardboard tubes and another makes wax stoppers with metal press. They are Panagle and Izod. A sign on the sid the table reads No Smoking. Scout Master Ward hands his cigarette to Gadge, who holds it away at arm's length.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: How many rockets you up to, Panagle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That enough for the Jubilee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gadge shakes his head. Scout Master Ward turns to Izod.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Izod, go fetch another pint of gun-powder from the armory shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Izod dashes around the corner. Scout Master Ward strides away. He shouts:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Redford! Halt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motorcycle skids to a stop in front of Scout Master W engulfing him in a thick cloud of dust. He coughs and wav his arms in the air. As the smoke clears, we see that the rider is a bronze, all-American-looking boy with blond ha He is Redford. His motorcycle has flames painted on the g tank. He tries to cover for himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safety-test, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vehicle appears to be in good working order. I'm just checking if -- 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckless cycling. Second warning. Next time, I take away the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gadge makes a note. Redford scowls. Scout Master Ward str away. He walks past a scout in a white apron cooking baco over a charcoal grill. He is Chef.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Morning, Chef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef rings a bell hanging on a post. Scout Master Ward arrives at a long picnic table. He sits down and opens a magazine called Indian Corn. There is a picture on the co of a scout troop crossing a bridge in Indonesia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first page. A caption across the top reads Scout Mast in-Chief. There is a drawing of a seventy-year-old man on horseback. He has silver hair and a moustache. A signatur below reads Commander Pierce. There is a quotation in lar text: "An eagle was never hatched from a goose's egg."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Scout Master Ward reads, all the scouts begin to join one-by-one. They range in age from twelve to fifteen. The unscrew the tops of tin mess-kits and assemble folding utensils. The chef brings a tray of scrambled eggs to the table. The scouts serve themselves noisily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward starts to take a sip of coffee from a m cup -- then stops. He looks up from his magazine.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Who's missing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward silently reels off a list of names, scanning the troop. He turns and shouts across the camp:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Shakusky! Breakfast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Scout Master Ward calls to Lazy-Eye:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Lazy-Eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lazy-Eye plays another tattoo. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward closes his magazine. He flicks his cigarette into a red bucket labelled Fire. He picks up a strip of bacon and chews on it as he rises to his feet an walks down the row of smaller tents. The last one is seal 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the front. Scout Master Ward stands with his hands on hips and says:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Shakusky? You in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward tugs on the tent's flaps. He frowns. He says to Gadge:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: It's zipped from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other scouts begin to gather with their tin breakfast plates in their hands, watching curiously while they eat. Scout Master Ward's voice softens:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward looks concerned. He produces a wooden- handled scout pocket-knife. He unfolds a few blades and gadgets and decides quickly on a thin tool with a hook on end. He crouches down and slips the hook through a small at the base of the flap, twists left and right, then pull briskly, unzipping the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lining of the tent is printed with images of trees an pine cones, and a plaid rug covers the floor. There is a locker, a gas lamp, a chair with a folded blanket over it and an empty cot. Scout Master Ward steps inside slowly, over, examining the space. He lifts the lid of the foot locker. He looks under the corner of the mattress. He pic up a piece of folded yellow notebook paper sticking out f under a pillow. He opens it and stares at it. He turns suddenly to the chair against the wall of the tent and sl it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is neat but slightly jagged hole the size of a basketball cut through the fabric in the back corner. Sco Master Ward looks to his staring troop.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Jiminy Cricket. He flew the coop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A one-room bungalow with a sign on the door that reads Is Police. There is a wood-panelled station wagon parked alongside it with roller-lights on the roof and a sheriff office insignia on the door. (This is the only car on the island.) A dock stretches from the cottage into a small 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: harbor. There is a launch moored at the end of it which b in the rough tide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silver Airstream trailer is parked under a tree nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A six-foot tall, forty-five-year-old man sits on a stool fishing from the side of the dock. He wears a short-sleev police uniform with a black necktie and a baseball cap. H glasses have clear, plastic frames and a strap. He is Cap Sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two grouchy, leathery, very old men in plaid flannel and hunting caps fish alongside Captain Sharp. A speaker on a post emits an electric buzz. Captain Sharp turns. He stan up briskly and says to one of the old men:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch my line, Edgar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small office with a desk, a file cabinet, and a two-way radio. Captain Sharp comes inside, sits down, grabs a microphone, and presses a red button on the side of it wi his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? This is Captain Sharp. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward's voice comes over a crackly speaker:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp, this is Randall Ward over at Camp Ivanhoe. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp pours himself a cup of coffee from a pot on hot-plate as he answers distractedly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Randy. What can I do for you? Over.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm not sure, exactly. I've got an escaped Khaki Scout. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Captain Sharp frowns slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Over.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One of my boys seems to have stolen a dug- out and some fishing tackle, ten pounds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOUT MASTER WARD (V.O.) (cont'd) of sundries, two bedrolls, plus an air rifle -- and disappeared. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp slowly stirs sugar into his coffee as he contemplates this. He says finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any idea why? Over.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No. He left me a letter of resignation. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheet of wide-ruled yellow paper which reads in a boy's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Scout Master Ward, I am very sad to inform you I can no longer be involved with the Khaki Scouts of North America. The rest of the troop will probably be glad to hear this. It is not your fault. Best wishes, Sam Shakusky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp scratches his head. He checks his watch. Pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we better notify his folks. Over.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: OK. Over and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clapboard cottage surrounded by a white, picket fence. sign on the door reads U.S. Mail. Captain's Sharp station wagon is parked in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young woman with her hair in a bun sits at an operator' switchboard eating a sandwich wrapped in wax-paper. She i Becky. She wears bulky head-phones with a microphone attached. Captain Sharp paces behind her. Scout Master Wa flips through a stack of letters and post cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bell rings on the switchboard. Becky plugs cords into sockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Diane. 10.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Becky, I have your person-to-person from Chesterfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold the line, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becky signals to Captain Sharp and Scout Master Ward. The sit down quickly and put on their own sets of operator he phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Chesterfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Split-screen. On one side of the frame, we see Captain Sh Scout Master Ward, and Becky. On the other side, we see a seventy-five-year-old man with a grizzled face sitting at kitchen table drinking coffee and smoking a cigarette whi white-haired woman ices a cake in the background. They ar Mr. and Mrs. Billingsley. Mr. Billingsley says into his

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, sir. This is Captain Sharp.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I received your message. Thank you very much. In fact, we've come to a decision, as a family, because this is only the most recent incident involving Sam's troubles, and it's just not fair to the others, so, unfortunately -- we can't invite him back, at this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp, Scout Master Ward, and Becky all look puzz Captain Sharp says evenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no cause for alarm, sir. We'll find him. We're just notifying you as a matter of protocol and so on.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I understand that. I'm notifying you of the situation on my end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm confused by that statement. You can't invite him back? 11.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not. He's a good boy, he's got a good heart, but it's just not fair to the others, you see? He's emotionally disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause. No one moves except Mrs. Billingsley icing he cake. Captain Sharp says finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I speaking to Sam's father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Billingsley frowns. He says, surprised:

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: No, sir. Sam's parents passed away a number of years ago. We're Mr. and Mrs. Billingsley. We're foster parents. Sam's been with us since last June.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Billingsley has stopped icing her cake. She watches Billingsley. Scout Master Ward interjects:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. This is Scout Master Ward speaking. Are you implying Sam's an orphan?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Well, it's a known fact. Of course, he is.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Why the hell doesn't it say that in the register? Excuse my language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward holds up a manila file-card. Mr. Billingsley shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I don't know. What register?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manila file-card. It is labelled Khaki Scout Register Sam Shakusky is typed across the top line. There is an address, health information, and a small, faded snap-shot stapled to the corner of it of a twelve-year-old boy stan in a sunny tobacco field. He wears his scout uniform with Davy Crockett-style coon-skin cap.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: We sent him a letter. It should reach you presently. 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward looks quickly through his stack of lett He stops and pulls out an air-mail envelope. He stares at Captain Sharp says forcefully but highly agitated:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Billingsley, I've got an escaped Khaki Scout. We're notifying you as a matter of protocol. You say you can't invite him back? You say he's an orphan? Well, I don't understand how that works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do with him?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BILLINGSLEY
dialogues.text: That's up to Social Services. They'll be in touch with you. They'll look after Sam. Good luck to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Billingsley hangs up the telephone. Becky pulls the c out of their sockets. Captain Sharp looks to Scout Master Ward. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becky opens a tin of home-made chocolate chip cookies. Captain Sharp declines one. Scout Master Ward tries one. looks very impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward stands on a bench addressing his assemb troop. The scouts are equipped for hiking with back-packs walking-sticks.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: You have your orders. Use the orienteering and path-finding skills you've been practicing all summer. Let's find our man and bring him safely back to camp. Remember: this isn't just a search party, it's a chance to do some first- class scouting. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lazy-Eye raises his hand. Scout Master Ward points to him

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Lazy-Eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your real job, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a math teacher. 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What grade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighth. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lazy-Eye shrugs. Scout Master Ward frowns.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: You know, we're, actually, kind of, in the middle of something, if you didn't notice. This is a crisis. Anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redford raises his hand. Scout Master Ward points to him.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Redford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he resists?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakusky. Are we allowed to use force on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not. This is a non-violent rescue effort. Your instructions are to find him, not to hurt him. Under any circumstances. Do I make myself understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scouts murmur their understanding. Scout Master Ward nods.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Scout Master Ward wheels back to Lazy-Eye:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: I'm going to change my answer, in fact. This is my real job. Scout Master, Troop 55. That's us. I'm proud of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scouts look impressed but slightly lost. Scout Master Ward says finally: 14.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Be leery out there. OK, let's get started. Where's Snoopy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skotak holds up a leash attached to a wire-haired terrier Scout Master Ward takes a sock with a fleur-de-lis on it of a paper sack.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Give him the scent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward hands the sock to Skotak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redford, Deluca, Nickleby, Lazy-Eye, and Gadge at the bac the group talking under their breath while Skotak waves t sock under the dog's nose:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard he ran away because his family died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard he never had any family in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's probably why he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you one thing: if we find him, I'm not going to be the one who forgot to bring a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troop moves in a wide line searching through a thicke skinny trees. Redford carries a net and a giant tomahawk sling. Deluca has a large hunting knife tucked under his belt. Panagle holds a walking stick with a cluster of nai sticking out on the end of it. Nickleby, Izod, and Lazy-E all wear bows and quivers of arrows strapped to their bac The wire-haired terrier strains at the end of a leash, sniffing down a foot-path. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward speeds up the river in a small boat wit out-board motor. He gives orders over a walkie-talkie. Ga steers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp stands on the doorsteps of various big hous showing the snap-shot of the missing scout to: an elderly woman, a house-keeper, a group of children, a priest. The all shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp drives his station wagon down a beach, thro a field, and over a bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp stands at the front door talking with Mr. a Mrs. Bishop. Mr. Bishop holds a glass of red wine in one and an open bottle in the other. Mrs. Bishop looks slight uneasy. They both study the snap-shot.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Camp Ivanhoe? That's all the way across the other side of the island. You really think a twelve-year-old boy could row this far in a canoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most likely not.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: (with a shrug) It's possible, Counsellor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I disagree, Counsellor. It'd take him three days, at least.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Two days, maximum.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not going to argue about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be that as it may, will you let me know if you see anything unusual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A binocular shot of Captain Sharp from overhead as he wal away down the front steps. He passes Lionel, Murray, and on their way up the path. They wear wet bathing suits and towels around their shoulders. Captain Sharp pats Rudy on top of his head. He dries his hand on the leg of his 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: trousers. He gets into his station wagon, backs out of th driveway, circles through the woods, and drives around to small dirt road a hundred yards behind the house. He stop the car. He gets out, sits on the hood, and lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy watches from the widow's walk with her binoculars. S lowers them. She looks curious. She raises them back to h eyes and sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bishop from overhead as she comes out the back door the house carrying a basket of damp laundry. She pauses a clothesline, looks left and right, then walks quickly int the trees. She crosses a foot-bridge and arrives at the d road. Captain Sharp stands up. They talk briefly but intensely. Mrs. Bishop leans against the car and stares i space. Captain Sharp touches her hair. Mrs. Bishop makes gesture with her fingers. Captain Sharp hands her his cigarette. Mrs. Bishop takes a puff, hands it back, and strides away again through the woods. Captain Sharp gets his station wagon and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A portable night stand. There is a reel-to-reel tape reco recording on it. A framed photograph next to it shows the Scout-Master-in-Chief posing with a troop in front of the Matterhorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front flaps are tied-open, and a mosquito net is draw hanging lantern flickers on a hook. A bugle plays a varia of taps in the distance. Scout Master Ward sits on a cot dressed in pajamas. He smokes a cigarette and drinks a gl of brandy while he speaks tensely into a microphone:

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Scout Master's log. September second. First day of search party for Sam Shakusky. Morale is extremely low, in part, I suppose, because Sam is, unfortunately, the least popular scout in the troop, by a significant margin. I'm worried, and I'm confused. Please, let us find him tomorrow. Please, don't let him fall off a cliff or drown in the goddamn lake or something. A terrible day at Camp Ivanhoe. Let's hope tomorrow's better. In fact, I'm going to say a prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward presses stop. He kneels down on the flo closes his eyes, presses his palms together, and whispers 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward zips up his tent and turns off the ligh Crickets chirp. Bats circle. The wire-haired terrier digs carefully through a pile of trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. A fast current runs along a shallow rav deep in the forest. The boy from the snap-shot rows a min canoe painted with Native American tribal symbols and severely over-loaded with boxes, bags, and blankets. He w a pellet gun slung on a strap over his shoulder and his c skin cap. He smokes a pipe. A sash across his chest is decorated with numerous small, embroidered patches. There a woman's enamelled brooch pinned to his shirt. It is a jeweled, black scorpion. He whistles to himself quietly a steers under a fallen tree-trunk and winds through gentle rapids. He is Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eddy under a willow tree. The end of the canoe is tied a branch, and the cargo is stacked on the shore. Sam cove the boat with a camouflage net and dresses the top with p needles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam hikes through a pass wearing an extremely large back- with stakes, metal poles, and two bed-rolls strapped to t bottom. He wears a compass on a string around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A binocular shot of Sam emerging from the woods into a wi meadow. The grass comes up to his chest and flows in wave He pauses to check his compass. He spins slowly one direc and then back the other while he stares at the dial. He l up again. He walks onward. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy lowers her binoculars. She stands at the end of a pa cut through the high grass. She has a leather folder in o hand, the portable record player in the other, plus a sma suitcase and her kitten in a basket at her side. Sam take his coon-skin hat slowly off his head. He strides across meadow. Suzy watches him approach. She swallows. Her lips part. Sam comes onto the path. He stops ten feet away fro Suzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy stare at each other. Silence. (NOTE: Suzy is slightly taller than Sam.) 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poster box with St. Jack's Church across the top. A pur ink mimeographed page is stapled to a bulletin board insi under the heading Summer Pageant, 1964. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Performed by the Choristers of St. Jack Wood and New Penzance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusk. A brick church at the top of a bluff overlooking th bay. It is overgrown with ivy and wisteria. There is a cemetery with a low wrought-iron fence. An organ plays inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Year Earlier

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A play is in progress. The set includes a long ark with a sail built on a platform behind the altar. Two teenagers crouched in the wings ripple a narrow, blue sheet across foot of the stage. (This is meant to be water.) The rest the room is dim, with tall candles flickering along the center aisle. The beams are draped with garlands. A large congregation fills every pew plus folding chairs against walls. More people sit and stand on the steps to the choi loft at the back and in nooks and corners. The members of brass ensemble seated beside the organist wait for their cue, following their sheet music with instruments poised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khaki Scouts and scout masters occupy the rear section of church. A very young troop in a slightly different versio the uniform fills a row near the exit. Sam sits on the ai He looks bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baritone built like a linebacker in robes and a fake be sings ominously on the stage. Cymbals crash. Sam stands u and discreetly wanders toward the side door with his hand his pockets. A slight, forty-year-old man in the same uni watches him from the end of the pew, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam quietly entering the lobby. The sound of the music deadens as he gently shuts the door behind him. He turns around and puts on a yellow scout cap with Junior Khaki stitched on the bill. The room is jammed with children dressed as animals, waiting nervously in a long line that 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: winds all around the space. They whisper and shuffle. A l woman stares through a small window into the church with hand on a doorknob. She is Mrs. Lynn. She snaps her finge suddenly without looking to the children. They fall silen Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lynn swings open the center doors. Music fills the r again. The first twenty of the children begin to sing. Th march out of the lobby, two by two. The woman closes the doors behind them, and the next group takes their place t wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks slowly among otters, monkeys, squirrels, and skunks, examining their costumes, periodically touching horns, tusks, and teeth. No one pays attention to him. He drinks a sip from a water fountain. He picks up a mint fr bowl and sucks on it. He slips out through a swinging doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam moves down a dark corridor. Voices murmur. He pokes h head around a corner. A rack of choir robes and cassocks blocks his path. He slides two of them apart and looks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five eleven-year-old girls in black leotards sitting on a bench in front of a mirror framed with light bulbs. They quietly and fix their make-up. They all wear wings on the arms and beaks on their heads. Suzy sits among them in bl feathers. Sam stares at her. He steps into the light silently. Suzy sees him in the reflection. The other girl turn around quickly, covering themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam removes his cap and takes another step forward. His e dart briefly among the other girls. He says to Suzy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of bird are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy hesitates. She looks to the girl next to her, who sa in a bossy voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sparrow, she's a dove, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam does not look away from Suzy as he interrupts, pointi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I said, "What kind of bird are you?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other girls all look to Suzy. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a raven. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy lifts her beak slightly higher on her forehead. The other girls look annoyed but transfixed. The bossy girl frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy's aren't allowed in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam does not look away from Suzy as he answers quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be leaving soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam points down at Suzy's lap. One of her hands is wrappe a bandage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got hit in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. How'd that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost my temper at myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is deeply intrigued by this. The other girls look puzzled. Suzy presses her hair back off her face. She wat Sam nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam. What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Suzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam nods with his eyes still glued to Suzy's. Suzy bites fingernails. The bossy girl rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not polite to stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam holds up his hand for the bossy girl to stop talking. Mrs. Lynn steps into the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LYNN
dialogues.text: Birds! Ready? 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lynn does a double-take. She snaps at Sam:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LYNN
dialogues.text: Who are you? Where'd you come from? Go back to your seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam hesitates. He spits the mint into a trash can, ducks through the clothing rack, and is gone. A skinny girl dre as an owl watches Suzy while the other girls hurry to the feet. She says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troops flood out from one side of the church while childr in animal costumes flood out from the other. They criss-c among grave-markers and head-stones. Sam stops abruptly, to face with the skinny owl. She whispers something, poin behind her, and thrusts a folded scrap of paper into Sam' hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vehicle crowded with scouts. Sam sits alone in the back row. He stares into space, entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy on-stage at the top of a pedestal with her arms in t air, spreading her wings. She is surrounded by the entire cast of singing animals. The music soars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam as he looks down at the piece of paper in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheet of pink stationary with an address in a girl's re felt-tip cursive and the words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The present. Sam and Suzy face each other in the wide mea Sam says carefully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you followed? 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam frowns and squints. He points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring a cat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy nods. Sam smiles. Suzy smiles. Sam takes a folded ma out of his pocket. He signals for Suzy to come closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you read a map?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do cartography.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam points to one of the patches on his sash. It has a protractor embroidered on it. He unfolds the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel we should go halfway today and halfway tomorrow, since you're a less experienced hiker, and you're wearing Sunday-school shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing on the map) Here's where we are right now. I'd like to pitch camp here by sixteen-hundred (which means four o'clock). How does that sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some beef jerky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam tears a strip of dried meat in two and gives half to Suzy. She tries to chew on it. Sam nods: 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy walk together down a hill, across a field, a through a wooded path eating beef jerky. They both smile continuously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you thirsty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if your throat gets parched, stick a pebble in your mouth and suck on it. You can quench your thirst with the spit, supposedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam shows Suzy some bits of green and yellow sticking out from under his coonskin cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I stick leaves under my hat. It cools your head down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good idea. It might help also if you didn't wear fur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True, but this adds camouflage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam stands in a clearing and pulls a handful of dry grass holds it in his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a trick. Throw grass in the air, and you can see which direction the wind's blowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam throws up the grass. It swirls and drifts vaguely. Su squints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unknown. I guess it doesn't really matter, as long as we cover our tracks. 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy stop to investigate and discuss: a patch of mushrooms, moss on a stump, ferns, poison ivy, and a low with purple fruit. Sam looks skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These might be poisonous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're huckleberries, in fact. Try one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy brushes off some dirt and eats a berry. Sam puts one into his mouth and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. Anyway, they're good for survival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy look through Suzy's binoculars at a deer drinking from a stream. Suzy whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows someone's watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree. Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just think he can feel us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy walk across a fallen tree over a stream. A s swims on the surface below them. Sam assists Suzy onto th far bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smell like perfume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my mother's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam picks up two pebbles. He and Suzy both put them in th mouths. They click against their teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought water, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy watch a small, green worm wriggling in the a swaying from a silk thread. They stare, wide-eyed. Suzy c her hand a few inches below it and moves it around in a circle. Sam shrugs. 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we catch him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trout bait. We need worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. The worm curls and uncurls itself gently. Sam nods

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. We'll let him live. Maybe I've got a licorice whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The banks of a large pond. All of Sam's and Suzy's bags, boxes, and suitcases are arranged around a small tent decorated with more tribal symbols. The kitten is asleep. and Suzy stand at the water's edge as he removes the camouflage net from the canoe and says gravely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How strong of a swimmer are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good. I broke our school record for the back-stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Well, I'm not that strong of a swimmer, so I wear a life-preserver. I think it's a good policy to get in the habit, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy both strap on vests belted with cork blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strip of bright red licorice on a hook under water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy in the middle of the lake. Suzy sits at one of the canoe fishing with a bamboo pole. Sam drapes his fingers off the side and stirs the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out for turtles. They'll bite you, if you put your fingers in their mouths. Let me see if I can catch this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam dips a net into the lake and brings it up with a smal turtle in it. He lifts it out of the net. It has red and yellow markings and a slightly damaged shell. Sam flips i over. The word Albert is written on the underside of the turtle in magic marker. Sam says blankly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody wrote on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fishing pole jerks in Suzy's hands. She yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stick's moving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam jumps to his feet and heaves the turtle with two hand It sails through the air across the pond and splashes dow with a whack. Sam yells an announcement:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fish on hook!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reel him in! Slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The canoe rocks violently. Suzy snaps:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam sits back down. Suzy winds the reel carefully. Sam sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam points to one of the patches on his sash. It has a ro and reel embroidered on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for fishing. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam twists a stick with a shoelace in kindling and builds small camp-fire circled with rocks. He cooks two fish wit bologna in a frying pan over a camp-fire. He throws in a of salt, grinds some pepper, and flips the fish in the ai He holds out a bite on a spatula to Suzy sitting on a log next to him. She tastes it. She looks surprised and nods

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. You know a lot about camping, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Khaki Scout. It's what I'm trained for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam points to one of the patches on his sash. It has frie eggs and bacon on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam serves the fish onto two tin plates. He says as they with folding forks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can feed your cat the guts and eyeballs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam points to a pile of bloody organs and bones on a page newspaper. Suzy frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. He only eats cat food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy points to a cardboard box. Sam looks inside. It is filled with ten cans of cat food. Sam raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else did you bring? We should make an inventory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam flips open a small, spiral-bound note-book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy opens the top of her portable record player. She displays it like a salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my record player. It works with batteries. Actually, it belongs to my little brother Lionel. I left him a note. Do you like music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam nods and makes a note. Suzy opens her leather folder. There are three L.P. records in it. She takes out one by French singer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my favorite record album. My godmother gave it to me for my birthday. She lives in France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam nods and makes another note. Suzy opens her suitcase. is filled to the brim with hard-back copies of fantasy bo It contains no other items of any kind (including clothin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are my books. I like stories with magic powers in them. Either in kingdoms on earth or on foreign planets. Also, time-travel, if they make it realistic. Usually, I prefer a girl hero, but not always. I couldn't bring all of them because it got too heavy. You can borrow any you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam nods and makes another note. Suzy produces a few more

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also brought my lefty scissors because I'm left-handed, my toothbrush, some rubber bands, extra batteries, and my binoculars, as you know. I forgot my comb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam surveys the entire collection of articles. He scratch his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it? No mess-kit? No flashlight? No canteen? No waterproof matches? Didn't you get the packing list I sent you in my last letter? 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that's what you're supposed to bring. I don't own a canteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Sam shrugs. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. We can share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam picks up one of the books. It is called The Girl from Jupiter. There is an illustration on the cover of a young alien princess with glittering tears on her cheeks. Sam examines the other books in the suitcase. He looks slight puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are all library books. In my school you're only allowed to check-out one at a time. Some of these are going to be overdue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam hesitates. He suddenly realizes something. He asks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you steal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Suzy nods reluctantly. Sam looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? You're not poor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy stares at the books. She absently brushes some dust them. She rearranges them slightly. She says finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might turn some of them back in one day. I haven't decided yet. I know it's bad. I think I just took them to have a secret to keep. Anyway, for some reason, it makes me feel in a better mood sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam thinks about this. He leans his chin against his fist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you depressed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy bites her fingernails. She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come? 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Suzy says philosophically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can show you an example, if you want -- but it doesn't make me feel very good. I found this on top of our refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy looks into her leather folder and shuffles through s pages. She withdraws a small pamphlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cover of the pamphlet. There is a drawing of a broken cup and the title "Coping with the Very Troubled Child".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam frowns. His eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy nods. Sam explodes with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam slaps his knee and shakes his head. Pause. Suzy dumps fish into the campfire and throws her metal plate like a frisbee into a tree trunk. It bounces off with a ding. Sh stands up and says coolly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really know how to make friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy walks away. She goes behind a bush and sits down on rock. She starts to cry. Sam looks stricken and confused. is very still. He gets up slowly. He tentatively approach the bush. He looks behind it. He takes two steps closer. stands above Suzy. He unties his neckerchief, crouches do and holds it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy looks to Sam. She hesitates. She takes the neckerchi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on your side. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy dries her eyes. She unfolds the neckerchief and stud its design. It is a brave shooting an arrow while leaning the side of a galloping horse. Sam motions to the books:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one's the best?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusk. Sam lies on his back on one of the bedrolls smoking pipe while Suzy sits Indian-style next to him. She reads aloud from a book called The Francine Odyssies. There is illustration on the cover of an enormous panther with a bloody sword walking behind a small girl in a nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes downcast, his kingdom in ruins, Mynar pressed his heavy paw through the rippling surface of the cool shallows and down to its stone floor. "My people once were lead by a great and noble beast -- and I no longer see his face in this reflection."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy looks to Sam. He is asleep. She takes the pipe out o his mouth and tips the ashes into the camp-fire. She draw blanket over his chest. She continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, on the Plains of Tabitha, Francine rested. There would be another time for war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining room. There is a long, wide, empty table with sixteen chairs around it. Tucked in the corner, Lionel, Murray, and Rudy sit at a folding card table. They have plates on place-mats and forks and knives. There is one e seat. Mrs. Bishop's voice booms, amplified, from the next

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Suzy! Dinner! I'm not going to say it again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Mrs. Bishop charges into the room with a steaming casserole. She wears an oven mitt on one hand and carries electric megaphone in the other. She sets the casserole o the card table and looks out the window. Through the thic 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of trees behind the house, a pair of headlights blinks. M Bishop checks her watch. She says sharply:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Where's your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but she borrowed my record player for ten days without asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel holds up a small, folded-up piece of pink stationa Mrs. Bishop snaps it out of his hand and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short note on pink stationary in a girl's red felt-tip cursive. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Lionel, I need to use your record player. I will give it back in ten days or less. Do not tell Mom. (Or Dad.) I will replace the batteries when I return. Signed, Suzy Bishop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bishop frowns. She bolts back out of the room. Her v

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Walt! Where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a loud thump upstairs. Mr. Bishop shouts from

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Right here! Why are you cursing at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior. Mr. Bishop leans out of an upstairs window. Mrs Bishop appears in one below. She yells up through the

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Does it concern you that your daughter's just run away from home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a loaded question. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bishop brandishes the note with her free hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Come down and read this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A radio squawks in the woods behind the house. Mr. and Mr Bishop turn quickly toward the sound. Mrs. Bishop looks tense. Becky's garbled voice says over a tinny speaker:

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward confirms they've had no luck. They're going home for the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a rustling and the sound of a car door opening - then the radio cuts off. Mr. Bishop frowns. He shouts:

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp emerges slowly from the dark, tangled in a bramble, hopping slowly on one foot as he unwinds a root around his ankle. He smiles awkwardly and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. Sorry to startle you. I was

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Nobody called the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, that's what I'm saying. The search party's not over yet. In other

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Suzy's missing, too! Go find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Where'd she --

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bishop disappears into the house. Captain Sharp and M Bishop exchange an uncertain look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp pans a spot-light back and forth in the darkness while he steers the car. The lamp has a short in 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and flickers with each bump. Mr. Bishop rides in the passenger seat. He stares ahead down the road and says to

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: How can we help her? She's got so many problems. It's getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bishop looks strangely to Captain Sharp. He asks:

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Whose fault is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but just for the record: ninety-five percent of all runaways return home within six hours. That doesn't do you any good right now. It's just a statistic -- but in all likelihood Suzy's probably hiding in the closet at her best friend's house playing Chinese Checkers at this very moment, as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: She doesn't have any friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Laura?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Laura?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bishop, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she upset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bishop looks baffled and disgusted. He throws his han into the air. He looks away and shakes his head. Silence. Captain Sharp wiggles some wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to get this spot-light fixed. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp and Mr. Bishop come to a stop and get out o the station wagon. They look dejected. The screen door ba open, and Mrs. Bishop quickly descends the front steps wi open shoebox full of letters in her hands. She says breathlessly, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: She has a pen pal! It's very intimate! They planned this together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp takes one of the letters and studies it. He says to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Shakusky. That's my escaped Khaki Scout. His family died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bishop takes a handful of the letters and flips throu them. He stops suddenly. He looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Holy Christ. What am I looking at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small painting on construction paper of a naked girl stepping into a bathtub. She wears a flower in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bishop continues to shout as she explains:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: He does watercolors! Mostly landscapes, but a few nudes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel, Murray, and Rudy watch from a downstairs window. Lionel takes a bite from a bowl of melting ice cream. Mr. Bishop stares at the painting. He squints at it and asks

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: She sit for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp and Mrs. Bishop look over Mr. Bishop's shoulder. Captain Sharp says calmly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The history of Sam and Suzy's correspondence. 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, dressed in a greasy jump-suit, writes at a work benc a garage while six teenagers take apart carburetors behin him. They are his foster brothers. Sam reads in voice-ove

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Suzy, You have a superb voice. You were my favorite animal in the program, by far. Please, find enclosed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy writes at a small desk on the upstairs landing while Lionel and Murray play a loud duet on a red piano behind (Rudy turns the pages of the sheet music.) Suzy reads in

dialogues.speaker: SUZY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Sam, Thank you very much. I got replaced as the raven because I yelled at Mrs. Lynn. After that I was only a blue jay, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam works in an alley emptying garbage from several small trash cans into a larger one. Mr. Billingsley watches television in a window, smoking a cigarette. He points to crumpled wrapper on the ground. Sam picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Suzy, I am sorry your brothers are so selfish. Maybe they will grow out of it. Sometimes people do things without knowing the reasons for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy reads a book called Disappearance of the 6th Grade. There is an illustration on the cover of a school-teacher levitating at the front of her classroom. There are sever watercolor pictures taped to the wall behind her. Most ar landscapes of small-town vacant lots. One is a swimming g in a bikini.

dialogues.speaker: SUZY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Sam, You are an excellent painter, especially trees and telephone poles. Is the girl in the water supposed to be me? My favorite color is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam stands in pajamas staring blankly, eyes wide, at a do house in flames next to a rusty swing-set. A dachsund sit next to him, also watching. Mrs. Billingsley comes runnin out of the house with a fire extinguisher.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Suzy, I accidentally built a fire while I was sleep-walking. I have no memory of this, but my foster parents think I am lying. Unfortunately, it is -- 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy stands in the kitchen looking out through a pane of glass with a hole smashed in the middle of it. Mrs. Bisho next to her with her hair hanging over the sink while the of them carefully pick bits of glass out of it.

dialogues.speaker: SUZY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Sam, I am in trouble again because I threw a rock through the window. My mother still has glass in her hair. Also --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five of Sam's foster brothers watch calmly as the sixth throws Sam against the wall then jumps on top of him, pin his arms to the floor while Sam struggles crazily.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Suzy, I have been trying very hard to make friends, but I feel people do not like my personality. In fact, I can understand why they might --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A classroom of sixth graders watches in a panic as Suzy throttles one of her classmates. The classmate flails and grimaces as she is strangled.

dialogues.speaker: SUZY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Sam, Now I am getting suspended because I got in a fight with Molly. She says I go berserk. Our principal is against me. Why do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam does sit-ups on a hard mattress in a basement room li with bunks. He counts out the repetitions under his breat There is a small, black and white photograph of a man and woman at their wedding tacked to the wall above him.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Suzy, I know your parents hurt your feelings, but they still love you. That is more important. If they --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy stands in a doorway screaming at her family while th watch wearily from the dinner table with forks and knives their hands.

dialogues.speaker: SUZY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Sam, I do think you should think of their faces every day, even if it makes you sad. It is too bad they did not leave you more pictures of themselves. Can you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam writes in his bunk crouched beneath a blanket with a Khaki Scout flashlight pointed at his paper. 38.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Suzy, Here is my plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy writes in her bed crouched beneath a quilt with a plastic lantern glowing beside her.

dialogues.speaker: SUZY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Sam, My answer is yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheet of wide-ruled yellow paper which reads in a boy's

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Suzy, When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheet of pink stationary which reads in a girl's red fe

dialogues.speaker: SUZY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Sam, Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy kneeling in the dark, crouched in front of an upper window with the shoebox of letters beside her. Outside, t woods are black beyond a moonlit field.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Suzy, Walk four hundred yards due north from your house to the dirt path which has not got any name on it. Turn right and follow to the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy raises her binoculars to her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will meet you in the meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. The end of the path cut through the hig grass where Sam and Suzy met the day before. Captain Shar Scout Master Ward, Mrs. Bishop, and Becky stand in two gr talking. Gadge and Skotak stretch a string with ribbons t to it from stake to stake marking a perimeter. Lazy-Eye w with the wire-haired terrier pulling at its leash. Other scouts search the field and scan the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp's station wagon and Redford's motorcycle ar parked in the dirt. 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bishop stands off to the side by himself poking at th ground with a stick. He has two black eyes, and half his is swollen and purple. Scout Master Ward asks Becky quiet

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. I think he went searching in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bishop says loudly without looking up from the ground

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: She stole the batteries out of my flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout Master Ward looks at Becky and grimaces. Becky rais an eyebrow. Mrs. Bishop stands next to Captain Sharp. The move slightly away from the others. Captain Sharp whisper quickly, almost inaudibly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's onto us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp looks surprised and defensive. He whispers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, he is?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: Of course, he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't we worried about that, then?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't know. Or, anyway, I thought I was wrong. Did you hit him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: No. He fell in a ditch. 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nickleby pops up from below the tall grass and thrusts an empty can of cat food into the air. He shouts excitedly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cat food! I think it's a clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group quickly gathers around Nickleby. Mr. Bishop snatches the can out of his hand and examines it. He says

dialogues.speaker: MR. BISHOP
dialogues.text: That's her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bishop throws the can away over his shoulder and walk off with his hands in his pockets. Nickleby runs after th can and picks it up again. Mr. Bishop continues down the hill. Scout Master Ward watches him. He asks Mrs. Bishop,

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT MASTER WARD
dialogues.text: Where's he going?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BISHOP
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bishop follows Mr. Bishop. Captain Sharp turns to th rest of the group and says briskly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. We know they're together. We know they're within a certain radius of this spot. I'm declaring the case with the county right now. Until help arrives:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sharp looks to Scout Master Ward as he points to various scouts and divides the group into teams:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm deputizing the little guy, the skinny one, and the kid with the curly hair to come with me in the station wagon. Randy, you drop-in and head up-river with the rest of your troop, then split-up on foot. Becky, call Jed and tell him to circle over this end of the island and fly low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A binocular shot of the seaplane flying in a pattern. It banks sharply. The binocular shot tilts down. Far below, the distance, Captain Sharp's station wagon rumbles along dirt road through the woods. The binocular shot pans wide the side of the river, Scout Master Ward's motorboat stop 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two scouts, tiny figures, pull the camouflage net off the hidden canoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy watches through her binoculars while Sam crouches be her. They are hidden behind a pile of rocks. Suzy says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found the canoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry at himself) Rats! I should've put more pine needles on it. Let's go. We're almost there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam lifts his backpack onto his back and slings his air-r over his arm. Suzy picks up her suitcases and puts the ki on her shoulder. They walk down a narrow path through a thicket. They emerge into a small clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Suzy stop in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deluca, Nickleby, Panagle, Izod, and Lazy-Eye stand in a along the edge of the woods ahead of them. Deluca brandis his hunting knife. Nickleby, Izod, and Lazy-Eye point the bows and arrows. Panagle holds his walking stick weapon. wire-haired terrier strains growling at the end of his le Deluca jerks him back. The kitten cowers. The sound of a motorcycle guns, and Redford bursts through the trees, po wheelie, and skids to a stop. He lifts his goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motor idles. Sam says finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you creeps want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redford shrugs and answers with a callous smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're a fugitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. Didn't you get my letter of resignation? I quit the Khaki Scouts. 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Sam quickly takes off his shirt and throws it asid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it doesn't matter, anyway. You don't have that authority. We've been deputized. Now are you going to come along peacefully or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam takes a deep breath. He pleads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to some reason: I don't like you. You don't like me. Why don't you stupid idiots just let us disappear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tempting, but I can't allow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deluca spits on the ground. He says to Suzy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be friends with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you just don't know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know him a lot better than you. He's emotionally disturbed because his family died. Nickleby, tie him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nickleby takes a step forward with his bow and arrow poin and ready. Suzy looks furious. Sam flips his air-rifle of his shoulder with a twirl. He points it at Redford and Nickleby. Nickleby hesitates. Sam says darkly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not cross this stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam motions to a twig on the ground in front of him. Sile 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doomed, Shakusky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redford revs the motor, pops the clutch, and races across clearing toward Sam and Suzy. The rest of the troop converges, yelling crazily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wide canyon echoing with shouts, screams, and a small explosion. One by one, Deluca, Nickleby, Panagle, Izod, a Lazy-Eye come running out of the trees and down the hill. Finally, Redford hobbles after them, limping and groaning clutching his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redford's charred, partially demolished motorcycle smolde in the branches of a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy stands on the edge of the ravine staring at the pair bloody scissors in her hand. She looks shaken. Sam takes scissors, cleans them with his fingers, and hands them ba to Suzy. He says gently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was him or us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy nods. She turns slowly away. Her eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy points. The wire-haired terrier lies on his back on ground with an arrow sticking out between his shoulder blades. The kitten licks at the wound. Sam and Suzy run o to the wounded dog. Sam crouches down, gently presses the kitten away, and says bleakly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got Snoopy through the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy has tears in her eyes. She slides her hands under th wire-haired terrier's body. She begins to hyperventilate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam puts his finger to the wire-haired terrier's neck. He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he doesn't. He needs a morgue. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to catch her breath) He's losing blood. Hurry. Where do we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy lifts the bleeding dog into her arms. Sam grabs her the shoulders. He locks eyes with her and says with grit
